newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS - News declines comment on bid report.
newsitem.headline: RTRS - News declines comment on bid report.

text.p: The News Corp Ltd said on Monday it had no comment on a British newspaper report that satellite broadcaster BSkyB was planning a bid worth more than four billion stg for media group Pearson Plc.
A News Corp spokeswoman in Sydney told Reuters the report was a matter for BSkyB, which was only partly owned by News.

Earlier on Monday, The Independent newspaper said in a front-page report said the bid preparations were at an early stage and it added that they were believed to have been mounted in cooperation with a U.S.-based media company.
A BSkyB spokesman declined comment on the report.
Pearson owns the Financial Times newspaper, Penguin Books and a number of television production companies.
Its current market capitalisation is just under four billion stg.
It hit the headlines last week when it appointed American Marjorie Scardino as its chief executive to succeed Frank Barlow from January 1.
She becomes the first woman head of a top 100 British company.
BSkyB has developed into one of British leading companies in the 1990s and now has a market capitalisation of almost 12 billion stg.
The report said that Pearson was discounting a full bid from BSkyB, believing instead that its real target was the company's television interests.
But the report added that BSkyB was understood to be interested in retaining the Financial Times and buying the 50 percent of the Economist which Pearson does not own.
It said remaining assets such as theme parks and Penguin books would be sold off.

BSkyB's advisers Goldman Sachs are believed to have already started to purchase Pearson shares as a prelude to a bid, the report said. It said BSkyB might eventually have to pay up to six billion stg to capture Pearson.
